hit the hay: If someone says they’re going to hit the hay, it means they are going to bed. It reflects a need for rest, possibly due to emotional exhaustion or weariness.
bite the bullet: To bite the bullet is to endure a painful or difficult situation with courage and resilience, often involving facing uncomfortable emotions or challenges.
cry over spilled milk: Crying over spilled milk means to dwell on past mistakes or misfortunes, often implying that it’s unproductive to worry about things that cannot be changed.
jump on the bandwagon: When someone jumps on the bandwagon, they adopt a popular trend or activity, often influenced by the emotions or opinions of others.
feel under the weather: Feeling under the weather means to be unwell or not in good health, expressing a physical condition that can influence one’s emotional state.
throw in the towel: If someone throws in the towel, they give up or surrender, often due to emotional exhaustion or the feeling that the effort is no longer worth it.
in the same boat: Being in the same boat means sharing a similar situation or predicament with others, usually involving common emotions or challenges.
on cloud nine: Being on cloud nine indicates a state of extreme happiness or euphoria, often resulting from positive emotions or experiences.
burn the midnight oil: Burning the midnight oil means working late into the night, often due to strong determination or intense emotions related to a project or goal.
get over something: Imagine something happens that upsets you, but as time goes on, you stop feeling as strongly about it. This means that you’ve gotten over it: you no longer worry about it and it no longer affects you in a negative way.
over the hill: If you’re getting older (especially over 50) and can’t be as physically or socially active as you used to be, you might say you’re over the hill. Be careful with this idiom, though, since it’s rude to say it about someone else.
hit the books: Literally, hit the books means to physically hit your reading books, but this phrase is actually used to say that you’re going to study.
hit the sack: The literal meaning of this would be physically hitting or beating a sack (a large bag), but idiomatically, it means you’re going to bed. You can also say hit the hay.
through thick and thin: When you’re loyal to someone, you support them no matter what happens, good or bad. This is an idiom you can use to say so.
off the chain: If you watch “America’s Got Talent,” you may have heard host Mel B exclaim that an act was “off the chain!” That means it was especially exciting or impressive—usually in a good way, though the expression can also mean “out of control.”
on the ball: If you’re on the ball, it means that you’re very quick to understand things or react quickly (and correctly) to a situation.
face the music: If someone tells you to face the music, they want you to deal with the reality of a situation and accept all the consequences.
ring a bell: When someone says something that you may have heard before, but don’t remember entirely, you can use this phrase to let them know it’s familiar but you may need a reminder.
blow off steam: If you’re experiencing some strong feelings and need to calm down, you can blow off steam by doing something to get rid of the stress.
cut to the chase: When somebody tells you to cut to the chase, it means that you’ve been talking too long and you need to get to the point. Be careful how you use this idiom; it could be rude or disrespectful if used with someone like a boss or teacher.
pitch in: Here’s a great video that teaches you 10 must know English idioms in six short minutes:
break the bank: Let’s all pitch in a few dollars so we can buy Sally a really good present for her birthday.
foot the bill: We need to finish this project on time, but let’s be careful not to cut corners and compromise its quality.
cash cow: I’d love to go on a luxury cruise, but the prices for those trips would break the bank.
out of pocket: Since it was my idea to eat at the expensive restaurant, I’ll gladly foot the bill.
pinch pennies: Investing in real estate has proven to be a cash cow for many entrepreneurs.
a drop in the bucket: I had to cover the travel expenses out of pocket, but I’ll be reimbursed later.
rolling in dough: While in college, I had to pinch pennies to make ends meet on a tight budget.
throw money down the drain: Donating a few dollars to charity is good, but it’s just a drop in the bucket compared to the overall need.
look like a million bucks: Ever since he started his own business, he’s been rolling in dough.
born with a silver spoon in one\u2019s m: Buying that expensive gadget turned out to be throwing money down the drain; I never use it.
to go from rags to riches: Wow, Mary, you look like a million bucks. I love your dress!
pay an arm and a leg for something: John was born with a silver spoon in his mouth, so he doesn’t know what it’s like to work hard.
to have sticky fingers: Jim Carrey went from rags to riches. He was once living in a van, but eventually became one of the highest-paid comedians in the world.
to give someone a run for their money: Nowadays, you have to pay an arm and a leg just for a tank of gas.
to pony up: The manager fired the cashier because he had sticky fingers. He stole more than $200 in a month.
to ante up: Joe really gave me a run for my money in the chess tournament. He almost beat me!
to up the ante: Pony up and give me the $5 you owe me.
break even: You’d better ante up and give me that $10 I loaned you last week.
to be close-fisted: The trip to the beach cost me $100, but I almost broke even after winning $90 in a contest.
to go dutch: Taking a week-long vacation would break the bank. There’s no way I could afford to do it.
shell out money: Carl is so close-fisted, he won’t even buy snacks for the Christmas party.
midas touch: Usually we go Dutch when we eat out, but this time I paid for her food since it was her birthday.
receive a kickback: I wish I hadn’t gotten that new car now that I’m shelling out $1,000 a month in payments.
living hand to mouth: Jane really has the Midas touch. Every business she starts becomes very successful.
to be loaded: The police chief was arrested after it was revealed that he was receiving kickbacks to ignore certain crimes.
make ends meet: The family has been living hand to mouth ever since their father lost his job.
as genuine as a three-dollar bill: Billy paid his Harvard Law School tuition with cash. His family is loaded.
in the red: I don’t make much from my job as a cashier, but I’m able to make ends meet.
in the black: Those supposed designer bags they sell on the street are as genuine as a three-dollar bill.
cost an arm and a leg: I’m in the red this month after paying that speeding ticket.
all ears: After working a couple of small jobs over the weekend, I earned an extra $500 and am back in the black.
heart of gold: If something costs an arm and a leg, it means it is very expensive, potentially causing financial strain and emotional stress.
keep an eye on: If someone is all ears, it means they are eagerly listening and paying full attention.
head in the clouds: Having a heart of gold means being kind, generous and compassionate.
kick the bucket: To keep an eye on someone or something means to monitor or watch attentively.
under one\u2019s thumb: Having your head in the clouds means being dreamy or not paying attention to reality.
put one\u2019s foot in one\u2019s mouth: To kick the bucket is a euphemism for dying or passing away.
twist someone\u2019s arm: If someone is under another person’s thumb, it means they are under that person’s control or influence.
stab someone in the back: Putting one’s foot in one’s mouth means saying something unintentionally embarrassing or tactless.
lose your touch: To twist someone’s arm would be rather painful if you took it literally, but it really means they’ve been convinced to do something they wouldn’t have done otherwise.
sit tight: While it still hurts, the idiomatic meaning of this phrase is not nearly as painful as literally being stabbed. What this actually means is to hurt someone who trusted you by betraying them.
eyeball it: No, this doesn’t mean you’ve lost your physical sense of touch. To lose your touch actually means to lose a skill you once had.
rule of thumb: This does not mean you sit down and hold your body as tightly as you can. If a person tells you to sit tight, what they really want you to do is wait patiently.
keep your chin up: Sometimes you don’t need an exact measurement: a rough estimate is good enough. When you estimate an amount of something based on how it looks, you can say you’re eyeballing it.
find your feet: If you hear someone say as a rule of thumb, they mean that it’s a general, unwritten rule learned from experience, as opposed to exact guidelines.
play it by ear: If you’re having a hard time, a supportive friend might tell you to keep your chin up. This means they are encouraging you to stay positive and not let difficult circumstances get you down.
knuckle down: If you find yourself in a new situation, like living in a new country and having to get used to a new college, you could say you need to find your feet. It means that you’re still adjusting and getting used to the new environment.
spice things up: If someone says they’re playing it by ear, it means they’re responding to circumstances as they develop without having a plan, like a musician jamming without a musical score.
a piece of cake: To knuckle down is to work hard or seriously at a task. If you tend to procrastinate, then you know when it’s time to do this.
cool as a cucumber: If you want to learn a few more English idioms about the body, see this post:
bring home the bacon: Instead of just buying Sam a birthday gift, let’s spice things up by taking him out for dinner.
in hot water: I expected the English test to be difficult, but it was a piece of cake.
compare apples and oranges: My friend is nervous about taking his driving test, but I’m cool as a cucumber.
not one\u2019s cup of tea: After my uncle retired from his job, he became a couch potato.
eat like a bird: Ever since her father was injured, she’s been working two jobs to bring home the bacon.
eat like a horse: Kevin is in hot water after committing tax fraud.
go cold turkey: I’m not sure which I enjoy more—pottery or dancing. It’s like comparing apples and oranges.
butter someone up: Camping is really not my cup of tea, so I’m going to visit my friend in New York instead.
food for thought: Don’t trouble yourself cooking such a big meal. I eat like a bird.
a smart cookie: My mother has to cook a lot of food when my brother comes to visit. He eats like a horse.
packed like sardines: I quit smoking cold turkey and never felt the need to go back.
spill the beans: I’m going to butter up my mom so she lets me hang out with my friends later.
a bad apple: Your proposal gave us a lot of food for thought. We’ll get back to you with a decision in a few days.
bread and butter: It shouldn’t be hard for a smart cookie like you to learn Spanish.
buy a lemon: Were you at the football game last night? We were packed like sardines in the stadium.
a hard nut to crack: Owen spilled the beans to Joyce about her surprise party, so she knows what’s happening.
have a sweet tooth: John’s the bad apple: he gets his friends to do dangerous and illegal things.
full of beans: Fishing is the bread and butter of the friendly people I met on the island last summer.
in a nutshell: The car looked so new and shiny. I had no way of knowing I was buying a lemon.
the icing on the cake: I definitely have a sweet tooth: I need dessert every night.
sell like hotcakes: Despite the long journey, the kids were full of beans when they arrived at the amusement park.
out of the frying pan into the fire: In a nutshell, the new policy aims to streamline the decision-making process.
under the weather: As the sole breadwinner, he works hard to bring home the bacon for his family.
a storm is brewing: Winning the championship was great, but getting a scholarship was the icing on the cake.
calm before the storm: The new smartphone is selling like hotcakes, with people lining up to get their hands on it.
weather a storm: Leaving my stressful job only to join a company in financial trouble felt like jumping out of the frying pan into the fire.
when it rains, it pours: If you’re feeling under the weather, you’re not your usual self and could be feeling a little sick.
chasing rainbows: This idiom is used in anticipation of trouble. Usually it means there’s been some kind of sign that this trouble is coming.
rain or shine: The air may be still before a storm actually hits. To say there is a calm before the storm is basically saying that things may be peaceful now, but it won’t last.
under the sun: It’s not exactly enjoyable to sit through a storm, so it makes sense that this idiom refers to enduring something that is difficult.
every cloud has a silver lining: Bad luck tends to come in batches. This idiom illustrates the phenomenon with the idea that any rain will become a downpour.
a rising tide lifts all boats: Have you ever tried to chase a rainbow? If you have, you know catching it is an impossible task. This is why someone pursuing a very difficult goal is said to be chasing rainbows.
raining cats and dogs: If you are dedicated to getting something done no matter what, you are willing to do it rain or shine. This is one of the rare idioms that’s also often used literally, for outdoor events that will take place whether it rains or not.
come rain or shine: This idiom refers to everything on Earth and is usually used as part of a superlative.
snowed under: A silver lining is the little bit of good that can be found in every situation, like sunlight peeking from behind a cloud.
break the ice: Boats of all sizes float at the same level: if the water rises, all the boats rise with it. Usually this idiom refers to how a stable economy often benefits everyone.
throw caution to the wind: When it’s raining cats and dogs, it’s raining very heavily.
in the eye of the storm: No matter the weather conditions, if something happens come rain or shine, it means it will occur without fail.
get into deep water: Being snowed under means being overwhelmed or inundated with a large amount of work or responsibilities.
up in the air: To break the ice means to initiate a conversation or ease tension in a social situation.
pour oil on troubled waters: If someone throws caution to the wind, they take risks without worrying about the consequences.
make waves: Being in the eye of the storm means being in the center of a difficult or chaotic situation.
go with the flow: For even more weather-related English idioms, check out these posts:
lost at sea: Learning winter sayings is the perfect way to face the winter! These English winter expressions add warmth and fun to conversations! This post has an array of winter…
sail close to the wind: This idiom is pretty close to the literal meaning: being in deep water means you’re in a tricky situation that is hard to escape.
make a mountain out of a molehill: If someone tells you that things are up in the air, it means that a situation is uncertain or unsure. It’s as though a ball has been tossed upward, and no one knows exactly where it will land.
gain ground: If you pour oil into the sea, it has a calming effect on the waves. You shouldn’t do that in reality, but you can use this idiom to say that you’re trying to soothe the tension following an argument.
walking on air: Much like dropping a stone into a pond to make ripples, to make waves is to cause trouble or change things in a dramatic way.
once in a blue moon: To go with the flow is to allow things to happen and accept them as they are, like a leaf floating along on the surface of a river.
many moons ago: Just as you’d be overwhelmed if you were stranded in the ocean, to be lost at sea is to feel unsure about what to do or that you don’t have any purpose or plan.
castle in the sky: This means to act just within the limits of what’s legally or socially acceptable. You may try to push boundaries and could sometimes cross the line.
down to earth: A molehill is very small, so if you act like it’s the size of a mountain, you are exaggerating the severity of the situation.
salt of the earth: If you’re gaining ground, you’re making good progress. This can mean physically crossing ground quickly, as in a race, or it can be figurative.
the tip of the iceberg: Use this if you feel very excited or happy. “Over the moon,” “on cloud nine,” “in seventh heaven” and “in good spirits” are a few more expressions you can use to talk about happiness.
bury your head in the sand: A blue moon comes every two to three years, so saying that something happens once in a blue moon is saying that it happens very rarely.
let the dust settle: This is one of those English expressions that’s a little bit formal or dated. You’ll most likely hear it in stories, or when someone is trying to create a dramatic effect. It means that something happened a long time ago.
clear as mud: This one sounds a bit like something from a fairytale, which makes sense since it is a daydream or hope that’s not likely to come true. Building castles in the sky refers to fantasizing about an unrealistic future.
as cold as stone: To be down to earth is to be modest, practical, unassuming and unpretentious.
between a rock and a hard place: If you are the salt of the earth, you are a good and honest person.
nip something in the bud: The majority of an iceberg is below the surface of the water. If someone says something is the tip of the iceberg, it means that there’s a lot more going on than what’s immediately obvious.
to hold out an olive branch: This one means that you’re trying to avoid a particular situation by pretending that it doesn’t exist. It refers to a popular myth that ostriches would stick their heads in the sand to “hide” when frightened.
beat around the bush: This means you are allowing a situation to become calm after something exciting or unusual has happened.
out of the woods: Mud is not a transparent substance, so this means that something is actually not clear at all.
can\u2019t see the forest for the trees: Stones can be very cold. If you say that someone is just as cold, you’re saying that they are unemotional or not empathetic. Cold as ice has the same meaning.
barking up the wrong tree: This means that you are faced with a choice between two equally unsatisfactory options.
branch out: This is to stop a bad situation from becoming worse by taking action at an early stage of its development.
turn over a new leaf: If you’re holding out an olive branch, you’re extending a hand of friendship and offering peace to a rival.
the grass is always greener on the other: This means you spend a long time getting to the main point of what you’re actually trying to say.
bear fruit: This means the worst part of a difficult situation is over, and the end goal is in sight.
